awd_titl_txt: Multiscale Study of the Respiratory Airway Mechanics for Cellular Inflammation
awd_abstract_narration:
Cellular inflammatory responses in respiratory airways during mechanical ventilation is a complex process dealings airway pressures/strains and cellular tissue compliance at multiple length scales. In order to gain understanding of this complex inflammation process and to aid in experiments, building computational simulations is necessary and may lead to a paradigm shift in mechanical ventilation for patients with respiratory failures. The overall goal of the research is to develop a multi-scale model of cellular inflammation in compliant lung geometry during mechanical ventilation. The specific research objectives are: (i) Development of an organ level model based on continuum description for studying the behaviors of the respiratory airway; (ii) Development of a tissue level model based on continuum description for studying the stress/strain behaviors of the airway tissue; and (iii) Development of a cellular level model based on discrete system for studying the behaviors of the cellular inflammation. Results of these computational simulations at multiple levels will be used to develop correlations that will be capable of testing the outcomes of various mechanical ventilation strategies with respect to airway pressures and stress parameters to minimize the potential for damage to the lung.

The intellectual merit of the research comes from integrating discrete cellular models of tissue inflammation with continuum description of tissue and organ level models to capture the complex pressures/stresses and cellular inflammation parameters in lung geometry due to mechanical ventilation. Besides developing models to understand the mechanical ventilation effects, the research results will provide new computational simulation models of the airway (fluid-solid interactions) and a rule based inflammation model at a cellular level which might help further to assess optimal characteristics for lung stresses and cellular inflammation parameters while minimizing the potential for damage to the lung tissue. The broad impact of this research stems from the development of multi-scale computational models which will advance our knowledge on mechanical ventilation strategies to avoid lung related injuries in patients. The research pioneers the beginning of a new approach to mechanical ventilation by combining advances in engineering simulation techniques with clinical applications. The benefits to society may include repairing lung injury in patients with respiratory failures resulting from multiple sources. If successful, this project will open a venue for patient specific computational simulations to avoid respiratory failures both in children and adults. The research results will be integrated into PI's educational activities and explore outreach activities with middle school and high school students through programs such as Richmond?s "QUESTERS" program, and YMCA Metro Teens at VCU. Dissemination will be through journal and conference publications along with a website for carrying out virtual simulations of respiratory failures and strategies to avoid them.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, a multi-scale model for cellular inflammation was developed for compliant lung geometry under mechanical ventilation by investigating respiratory mechanics at the organ, tissue and cellular levels. Coupled fluid-solid mechanics simulations as well as cellular automata rules for stretch induced inflammation were conducted in demonstrating the potential of the developed multiscale studies.

 

Several computational models were developed for lung bifurcations under mechanical ventilation to investigate the respiratory mechanics parameters (velocity, pressure, wall shear stress as well as stress/strain). Based on the simulation studies conducted, the respiratory mechanics parameters are affected along the lung bifurcations. Maximum pressure drop appeared in lower generations, and medium sized airways showed higher resistance to airflow. Results also showed that resistance decreased as the cross sectional area increased in the lung model. In addition, the simulation studies conducted on alveolar sacs illustrated that respiratory dynamics might lead to different pressures/strains. The results from the inflammation model indicated that for the strain conditions considered, the model is capable of predicting the innate healing capacity of the tissue. In other words, the tissue is capable of accommodating some amount of damage without breaking down the innate healing capacity. However, as the strain magnitude increases, the tissue is not able to accommodate the inflammation, and innate healing capacity breaks down.

The cluster analysis of fluid-solid simulation data revealed that the clusters of airway strain data are correlated to airflow characteristics. The subgroups revealed by the hierarchical method corresponded well to airflow characteristics in specific airway generations. The cluster analysis study suggests that a careful examination of strain data with more sophisticated analysis methods may help to gain additional insights into the characteristics of airflow in normal and diseased lungs.

The visualization of results obtained on the CA inflammation simulation grid revealed certain aspects of inflammation dynamics in terms of dead cells, fibroblast and macrophages spatially in the overall system. Visualization results suggest that certain inflammation conditions would lead to a distinct pattern on epithelial cells.

 

The novel multiscale model developed which integrates organ, tissue and cellular levels to address lung inflammation under mechanical ventilation. The computational simulation studies conducted demonstrated that the multiscale modeling can be used to investigate lung inflammation under mechanical ventilation. In addition, the integrated multiscale model can be used to develop ventilation strategies to reduce inflammation in lungs in future studies. Broader impacts include graduate/undergraduate student training, undergraduate projects and research integration into the curriculum, and expanding the project to include other investigators. The research was presented at several conferences as well as meetings. Attracted several underrepresented students to this project to pursue bioengineering research and provided opportunities for advanced studies.


Last Modified: 10/05/2016
Modified by: Ramana M Pidaparti
